First off, the story is not only moving and impactful, but long. You don't actuall come across the intro until about 30~ minutes in. That's just a estimate, but it honestly felt the opening came in where other VN closing credits would start rolling.

Secondly, the entire VN is voice acted. Voice acted tremendously well, for that matter. Even the main protagonist has not only a voice, but a face as well.

Not only that, but the art in this game is amazing. At first I thought I was delusional, but every character's eyes and mouths move. Every character and background scene really immerse you into the story the developer wanted to portray.

10/10, only regret regarding this game is the fact that I didn't buy it sooner.

reviewText:
If you knew that the world was going to end soon, how would you want to spend your remaining time? What would change for you, how would your priorities shift? Assuming you'd find an opportunity to escape, would you choose a future of perpetual narrow walls and cramped spaces over a short time of ultimate freedom followed by certain doom?

For the people living in the world of eden*, these questions are no longer abstract.

MangaGamer delivers the English release of this 2009 title by minori to Steam. eden* is a kinetic novel (a story without choices or gameplay) about the last few people on a dying planet. Its most unique selling point compared to similar titles is its visual presentation: Instead of the waist-up character sprites positioned in front of static backgrounds that we are used to from most modern visual novels, it relies almost entirely on scene-by-scene custom images, each one carefully designed to take character positions and camera perspectives into account. This gives the experience a very cinematic feel, quite literally reminiscent of movies, compared to other titles of its kind. Most scenes also features blinking eyes and lip syncing with the Japanese voices, which makes it impressively lively.

Needless to say, the asset quality is excellent throughout, starting with the backgrounds ranging from the painterly to the borderline naturalistic. The same attention to detail extends to the characters who, despite the multitude of poses and perspectives, always appear consistent, unique, and alive. From what I can tell as someone who does not speak Japanese, the voices really fit well, and coupled with the competent sound design and the soundtrack by Tenmon (if you happen to enjoy Makoto Shinkai's movies: yes, that Tenmon), which expands a small number of recurring motifs into a gripping soundscape, this is an aural experience that you are unlikely to forget.

The story revolves around Warrant officer Ryou Haruna and his assignment to guard a remote research facility during the planet's final moments. A peculiar (but largely unspecified) astronomical phenomenon is going to wipe out all life on Earth, and humanity is putting the finishing touches on a centennial plan to migrate into space and search for a new home. One component of this plan are the felixes, genetically engineered superhumans whose intellect propels scientific progress far beyond its normal pace. However, there are dissenting voices claiming that humanity should face its ultimate fate head-on instead of trying to escape, so military protection is granted to essential actors within the plan ‚Äì in particular to Sion, the supreme felix, mastermind behind the giant starships and humanity's savior.

The central themes of eden* include destiny and free will as well as the morality of living one's life for someone else. Ryou, as the self-described military's attack dog
date:
and Sion, as the people's only hope to keep on living, are both so devoted to their duties that they have fallen out of touch with their own humanity. Circumstances force them to confront their deeply buried sense of self and be thrust before the most pivotal decision of their lives: to keep on living in the narrow golden cages of their own design, or to choose the ultimate act of defiance and experience the freedom and joy that they had always denied themselves, living life to the fullest until the curtain falls.

The writing tends to focus on character interaction and personal growth over story complexity ‚Äì eden* is all about the human condition, not about hard sci-fi. In fact, even the scientific details of the end of the world are almost completely glossed over. If you are looking for an apocalyptic sci-fi story with cool technology, this isn't it. Rather, the focus on the characters is so strong that it could be described as downright melodramatic in parts, insofar as that can be a good thing. It features countless goosebumps-inducing, memorable, quotable moments that easily smooth over the fact that some of the tension maybe could have been resolved in easier ways, or that there's a certain degree of plot convenience constructing the situations that are most interesting for the characters. It all ends up feeling very complete and satisfying.

All in all, I can recommend eden* without much in the way of caveats. If you dislike visual novels or anime-style art, odds are you have not read this far down. If you like visual novels but you're not sure if this one is worth your time, my answer is that it is. I also recommend avoiding playtime estimates. Reading speed varies from person to person anyway, but the later parts of this story work best if you can empathize with the sense of impending dread that the characters are feeling. For them, any day, any moment, could be the last one. It'll be more fun for you if you can get lost in that feeling as well, instead of calculating how many hours you might have left. Even if you have little to no experience with visual novels, this one is probably a better one to get started than most titles currently on Steam. With the above-mentioned reservations in mind, eden* easily gets a positive recommendation from me.

reviewText:
It's very rarely I stay up until past midnight to beat a game, let alone Visual Novel. This game just did it.

eden is a kinetic visual novel with almost no required input whatsoever from the players, as the game naturally flows by itself. No branching story, no multiple endings etc. Be it so, it is brilliant on its own. The characters, the story, the soundtrack, all fit together.

Many people say the artwork or graphic is stunning. It is true. There's a real art involved in this game. While it's just a mere 2D pictures, the backgrounds of each frames are nicely put together and designed, smooth flows between the transitions. The characters arts are what you can expect from Japanese games, pretty. Moreover, there's a nice design like characters eyes' blink and their expression changes, lips move in sync accordingly when the mood changes/talks. Simple touch, but meaningful - it makes everything as a whole more lively. Although yes, I do have one complaint, that is - the eyes of those chars are a bit too big overall, makes it a bit weird.

Don't forget the important part for Visual Novel - it's the voice acting. While bunch of VNs abandon the voice acting because of many reasons, eden doesn't neglect it. The voice acting here is simply too good and unquestionably high production value. The actors really really pushed themselves to the limit, the emotions they bring through sheer voice acting alone is too incredible whether they portray happiness or sadness, they do it correctly. Can't deny this one is probably the strongest element this game has. That said, I'd recommend you let the game plays for you, so you get the fullest experience from hearing the voice acting. Voice acting is done in Japanese while the subtitle is in English. As someone who watches a lot of anime, I really appreciate it.

Then there's a mixing element of VN, story. The story starts out slowly and seemingly simple - our protagonist Ryou is assigned to protect military base and the female protagonist Sion. But as the game progresses things getting more intense - until the first act in Military Base ends -, and the last half of the game where Ryou and Sion away, it starts slowing down again. You'll mostly see development of Ryou and Sion's relationship, how two humans with very different background fall for each others. Sad moment, happy moment, funny moment, sad again rinse and repeat. Roller coaster storyline, but by no means bad. In fact, it's very well written when combined with the game arts and voice acting. Can't say much without spoiling, and it's not funny to spoil people's experience on VN game, isn't it? Do note, again, this is a Kinetic VN. There's only one ending as an end result of one linear story and despite you know the ending is coming as you imagine and you don't want it to come, you can't stop playing.

(....even I shed a tear or two watching the ending...)

Now there's a con. The game's performance is a bit bad. It does not support controller natively, and this is an annoyance for people who love to lay down comfortably on the bed while reading the texts. There's also a major problem with Steam Overlay (the Developer admitted it already, and can't fix it with their current resources) so people might have problem taking a screenshot or two. I also had a problem launching the game, not until I complained endlessly and had the Developer fixed it with beta branch which I'm currently using.

I also have to mention that the OSTs are not included in this Steam, be it within the game files so you can listen to them using Winamp for example, or being sold as DLCs. Too bad, would love to grab 'em - the soundtracks are really good. Here's one full song for opening movie from Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AL2ZTgbgQdg

eden is about ten hours long if you keep playing like my pace - letting the game does everything by itself.

VN is a genre that's not too popular on Steam, but overall, eden is a worthy game for any VN fans.

9/10

reviewText:
Eden is a visual novel set in the near future with Earth on the brink of destruction. We see the story through the eyes of an elite soldier called Ryou Haruna who is a personal guard to Sion, the Earth's lead scientist. We are just a passive observer and have no control over anything except when to start the next line of dialogue. There are no decisions to be made or any dialogue choices here. It does make your character more interesting and it makes for some pretty tense situations in where you hope he does the ‚Äúright‚Äù thing. But that also means you will be doing nothing but right clicking from start to finish which can be a turn off considering it is a lengthy game that took me about 12 hours to complete.

Options menu doesn't have much to it but a very neat feature is that you can turn off individual characters voice actors if you don't like there acting. Can't speak of the quality of acting as it is all in Japanese with subtitles being in English. Starting off you are in a field with Sion and it's all calm and happy. After a short while you are teleported back to the events that got you there which was kind of daunting and that intro served no purpose other then taking the impact out of scenes, as you already know both Sion and Ryou will be fine. Anyways, after the intro you will be on your way to a secluded island masion which is housing the renowned genius Sion who is working on her lasts steps to get mankind off of the dying planet.

Even though the world is about to end and Sion is nearly done with her work there are infiltrators that want to kill her. The game does not handle intrigue and mystery well. For example someone says ‚ÄúShe is a...‚Äù and the game fades to white and teleports you to another point in the future leaving you clueless as to where you are or what you are doing now. If you don't want us to know about it yet just don't bring it up. Another scene has you killing an infiltrator but you never see it happen, instead you are teleported a bit forward in time after the murder happens, leaving you wondering ‚ÄúWait. He is dead now? Well, okay then.‚Äù  It does this every time something mildly interesting happens which makes the game an utter chore to play until you escape the island.

Characters don't help at all either. Most are very unlikable which would be perfectly fine if they didn't try to play them off as good guys later on. Especially your character. He is supposed to be some elite solider that doesn't question orders but comes off as an extremely paranoid antisocial psychopath. That would make sense though the game never builds him up as a character or shows what he has been through to make him so psychopathic. Seeing his transformation from a sad kid to a hardened soldier would have been a much more interesting tale than anything on offer here. It is an interesting setting, humanity went bunkers after the red star in the sky was confirmed to destroy Earth and started a World War. Afterwards they focused on escaping the dying planet but some people refused to leave and started a guerrilla style war against the government.

But no, there we are stuck in a mansion with a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• protagonist and nothing much of interest going on. It really picks  after you escape the mansion though. As to be expected from this game it doesn't tell or show about your journey or how you avoided the military after escaping, you just teleport to a safe house. In that environment is where the game really shines. Sion being sick to the point of dying any moment really tugs on the heart strings. She is a super genius but she has been so sheltered that she does not know how to do the most basic of things like cooking or brushing her hair. You take on a father like role until things get romantic which is uncomfortable considering she has the body of a child. That is very late into the game though, do not be expecting a romance game, it is more of about taking care of a dying ‚Äúchild‚Äù.

Late in the game they also introduce the only other decent character besides Sion. It is entertaining watching our psychopath Ryou bully her, though Ryou will never become a likable character. Eden does a far better job mixing day to day comedy and sadness in events leading into the end of the world than trying to tell an actual narrative. There is nearly no ‚Äúfan service‚Äù except for one scene showing a girl in a bikini which was a nice change a pace from most Visual Novels.  Our character does like to stare at breasts though and probably spends more time looking there than at their faces. You can also buy a different version over at MangaGamer.com that features H scenes if you are interested but the story is perfectly fine without it.

One thing that really helps set the mood is the amazing soundtrack featured in this game. All the songs are top notch and really amplify the powerful moments. Artstyle is great though the environments are nothing special. This is a strange title. It does nothing right story-wise other than get you to care about Sion. If it didn't reveal right off the bat that you will escape safely there might have been some tense or interesting moments in the mansion which is a shame as the intro served absolutely no purpose. Eden did something right though since even if we all know how it will end you can't help but see it through to the end. It's not awful but it is a very slow burner and has neither the characters, the overall objective or the story to hold your interest until you reach the good parts. Something like finding out secrets about the facility, having the infiltrators be an actual threat or having meaningless dialogue options would have done wonders to alleviate the boredom. When all is said and done the last few hours are pretty memorable and emotional which does save the game in my opinion. Recommended to Visual Novel fans with a lot of patience.

reviewText:
Pardon my rambling thoughts ahead, afterwards I'll break down some basic pros and cons.

When I think about this game, I tend to gravitate towards comparing it to Narcissu.  Both are short kinetic novels, both deal with heavy topics like death.  But I think Eden* handles its topics a lot more interestingly than Narcissu.

A lot like Narcissu, death is a looming inevitability on the minds of the main characters.  For Narcissu, the constant talk of death and hopelessness turns the story into a drawn-out slog with an inevitable conclusion.  The characters don't really grow or noticably change over the course of the story.  Eden* handles the same concepts in a way that is a lot easier to swallow.  It isn't a spoiler to say that the main heroine dies in this story.  But how it handles that character death makes all the difference.  Eden* uses every chance it gets to develop its main hero and heroine into interesting characters with detailed motivations.  Where Narcissu was primarily about picking a better place to die than a hospital, Eden*s characters  use their struggles with their own mortality (either due to physical illness or the approaching end of the world) to learn to live life to its fullest with what time they have left.

Coming back and reading Narcissu again recently after having not read it for several years left me feeling depressed and almost...empty.  It was a soul-sucking experience.  But Eden*, despite being at times equally dark, sometimes even moreso because the characters were so much more three-dimensional, left me feeling uplifted and more positive about life.  I felt like it had really successfully communicated to me how important living my limited days on this earth to their fullest is.  So I think that's really a victory for this game's storytelling.

Now that that's out of the way, pros and cons.
+Great art.  This is subjective, of course, but if you don't mind the Key/Visual Arts-style GIANT ANIMU EYES, the spritework is great.  The occasional sweeping vista of fields or mountain lakes look great too.
+Great writing.  I only recall seeing a few minor typos, and it all read very smoothly over the 7 hour experience.
+/-  Music and general sound design was competent, but I don't recall anything hugely impressive.
- This isn't really surprising to anyone that has played a visual novel before, but there are no resolution settings.  You have windowed and fullscreen.  I just played in windowed.

Verdict: if you're looking for a book-like experience and don't mind moe-style eyes, pick this game up.  It's a beautiful story and you'll love all the characters by the end.

reviewText:
tl;dr - Recommended with some heavy caveats. It's good, but not great. A decent premise and some characters who don't stick completely to type make it better than most visual novels, but too many cliches drag it down and the ending feels like a cheat.
The world's about to end, and there's nothing anyone can do about it. After decades of civil war the last of the human race has come together to realise a desperate plan. A genetically engineered young scientist, smartest of her kind, has come up with a design for a fleet of spaceships to ferry the survivors off-planet to start over somewhere else. And a weary, battle-hardened soldier takes an unusual posting to the secluded military base where the genius is holed up.

eden* is a little more mature than your average visual novel, then: sure, it's merely an elaborate excuse for two wounded birds to fall for each other, and the daft character designs make that clear (the tiny, waifish heroine with her huge, vulnerable eyes!) but it's refreshingly low-key in many respects. No aliens, no elaborate pseudo-science, no brazen monologuing, just a clock slowly winding down.

It's a book you click through - totally linear, no branches - and the plot struggles to find its feet a bit. The localisation is occasionally dire, with some truly awful, dreary prose early on. The few action scenes are borderline incompetent, and the attempts at comedy aren't much better (because maid uniforms and sexual harrassment in the military are hilarious, am I right?).

tl;dr - Recommended with some heavy caveats. It's good, but not great. A decent premise and some characters who don't stick completely to type make it better than most visual novels, but too many cliches drag it down and the ending feels like a cheat.
The world's about to end, and there's nothing anyone can do about it. After decades of civil war the last of the human race has come together to realise a desperate plan. A genetically engineered young scientist, smartest of her kind, has come up with a design for a fleet of spaceships to ferry the survivors off-planet to start over somewhere else. And a weary, battle-hardened soldier takes an unusual posting to the secluded military base where the genius is holed up.

eden* is a little more mature than your average visual novel, then: sure, it's merely an elaborate excuse for two wounded birds to fall for each other, and the daft character designs make that clear (the tiny, waifish heroine with her huge, vulnerable eyes!) but it's refreshingly low-key in many respects. No aliens, no elaborate pseudo-science, no brazen monologuing, just a clock slowly winding down.

It's a book you click through - totally linear, no branches - and the plot struggles to find its feet a bit. The localisation is occasionally dire, with some truly awful, dreary prose early on. The few action scenes are borderline incompetent, and the attempts at comedy aren't much better (because maid uniforms and sexual harrassment in the military are hilarious, am I right?).

But slowly, surely, it gets better. You realise characters have depth, and nuance, and they aren't just sticking rigidly to stereotypes. Potentially cliched plot beats just get tossed aside with a surprisingly level-headed Nah

reviewText:
What a great visual novel!
This was the second visual novel I actually finished from beginning to end (the first being Flyable Heart) and it was worth every minute. The story has so many feels and the characters are great, with just enough thought put into them to make you care about each one. As for the artwork, the backgrounds were breathtaking at times, and the character sprites, although limited, were also beautiful. One of the best aspects of this game though was the background music, and how it complemented the story perfectly.

Overall an amazing visual novel. Great for those looking to get into visual novels as it has a relatively short story (it took me about 8 hours to read it all) and it does not have choices. The lack of choices might equate to a lack of replay value, but the fact that I don't have to go back and reread a large chunk of the story multiple times in order to get the ENTIRE story is something that I enjoy.

Buy this game if you are looking to get a good taste of visual novels. Also, the funds collected from this game are going directly to the translation of the next game by this company.

[Synopsis] Over a hundred years ago, humanity learned of a humungous comet, one massive enough to obliterate Earth itself. Now, as the day of destruction closes in, most of the human race has already evacuated into space in search of a new beginning. It was at this time that she met Ryo, a soldier seemingly void of life and purpose, who was ordered to become her bodyguard. Now, let the curtains rise on the last love story on earth‚Ä¶

[Review] Eden* is undoubtedly one of the best and most touching VNs currently available on Steam, and is a must buy for anyone looking for a beautifully written and somber story accompanied by fantastic visuals and music. Though there are certainly flaws within the VN itself, I believe the pros far outweight the cons of this VN.

Pros:
‚Ä¢ Characters - Each and every one of the characters is written with care. Though each falls into a certain trope in their early stages of development, depth is carefully layered upon each character that far surpasses their original trope.
‚Ä¢ Music - Eden* has some of the most pleasantly somber tracks I've heard in any VN. Many classical instruments are used including the violin and the piano.

reviewText:
You may think that since I have only played for about 3 hours I have no right to write a review, but I‚Äôm starting to fear that I‚Äôll burst if I hold this in. I may update my review if I ever manage to finish this game or my opinion changes.

I still remember the first visual novel I ever played. It had pretty bad graphics with broken anatomy for the character portraits, very few CG‚Äôs, 12 different soundtracks of horribly repetitive music, several flaws in its coding which made things confusing at times and not the best English. But the fact stood that a single person with English as a second language had worked and produced an amazing visual story with deep characters that touched the heart.

Eden* is the exact opposite. The graphics are beautiful, characters have animated eyes and mouths, there are a huge amount of CG‚Äôs, fully animated opening, beautiful soundtracks and sound effects, full voice-acting, perfectly coded and excellent English text. But Eden* with its mind-numbingly dull story and flat characters have succeeded in completely killing my interest for visual novels. Eden* is for some reason passed off as a visual novel but is really a kinetic novel.

From the moment I started up Eden* I was bored, but told myself that I was being unfair and should play more before passing judgement. But no matter how much further I went things never turned out interesting and the story only became duller and duller. At certain parts of the story there were moments that could have been interesting but was completely cut out and skipped over because god forbid we have something remotely interesting.

The protagonist is Ryou Haruna who is the most perfect boy in the world, the best soldier of them all, dark and totally edgy, has a dark past and charms all the girls simply by existing. He is a terrible person but the story progresses as if he‚Äôs a good person with characters magically being in love with him and completely trusting him for no reason.

Other characters include Sion who is the most perfect loli in the world, the most intelligent being on the planet despite not being able to wash her own hair and everyone calls her ‚Äúthe messiah‚Äù. Elica who is a ditzy maid that takes care of Sion. Lavinia who gets her panties wet over bladed weapons and Inaba who drinks on the clock.

I couldn‚Äôt for my life care for any of the characters or their backstories and only found them infuriating. Every character‚Äôs personality is horribly typical and cookie-cutter. All I needed was an introduction and then I had immediately grasped their entire character and could predict their actions from there on. The conversations between the characters are so flat and unrealistic it feels like everyone is talking to a wall.

When I read the description, saw all the good reviews and saw that it was developed by the popular Minori I honestly expected a good story with deep characters. For the first time I wish that Steam issued refunds. The only consolation I have is that I bought it on sale so I didn‚Äôt suffer the full blow of the 20 euro that this game is selling for.

I would not recommend this for anyone with regular standards. If you however have a strong liking for dull storytelling, underdeveloped characters, anime characters whom look like they‚Äôre 12 years old and old-fashioned cheesy drama this would satisfy your needs.

A powerful story about love, life and what it means to live. The story involves the final days of the planet Earth which may seem like a cheap way to inject drama but, honestly, that part of the story may as well be an aside. The fact is that the main story is between our two main characters and it could have just as well been told in another setting while still remaining as powerful. It's very well written with one caveat...

The pacing for the first half is incredibly slow. If you're not a patient person, you may have trouble dragging yourself through it. Speed reading or skimming along until the main characters get together wouldn't be a terrible idea if you feel yourself getting disinterested because there is a great ending to this story, despite the slow start. This is a long story and they get together at about the midway point so you won't be robbing yourself of much by skimming a bit. Lastly, just an FYI, this is a kinetic novel meaning there are no choices, branching paths or interactions.

As far as the artwork goes, it's mostly top-notch. The characters are often incorporated into the backgrounds instead of the standard VN format of having a background layer with static pop-up" characters in front of it. There are a few frames of Major Inaba that are comically bad and I question how they ended up in the game when the rest is so well drawn but aside from that
recommended: it's a great story if you have the time (and a little patience) to put into it. A bit slow to start but it has a fairly powerful finish. I recommend it."

reviewText:
A well illustrated visual novel, with a moving, although somewhat empty story. Set in the future, the earth is facing its destruction due to causes left largely unexplained. The protagonist Ryou is sent to guard a secret facility. The facility was used to research a new genetically modified form of human with hyper intelligence. These modified 'felixes' were used to research and design the ships to be used to escape the destruction of the planet. The story is told half through flashback about the events surrounding Ryou, and the final days of the doomed planet.

Ultimately however the story comes off as somewhat unsatisfactory. Due partially to its nature as a kenetic visual novel. There are no choices, and no options for further reading. The game presents a lot of interesting material, but it is entirely set within either the research facility or the countryside. There is little to no opportunity to learn about the rest of the world. Ultimately this is a love story between the hero and heroine, and the rest takes a backseat with no chance to bring to light anything about the interesting background world. If you like a romance, this is a very good one. But it falls quite flat in other areas. Particularly as the story is actually at its core very simple and straightforward, it could take place in any setting with minor modifications. It therefore doesn't make the best use of the world nor characters it has come up with.

Pros:

- Overall well illustrated, pleasing on the eyes.
- Mostly realistic, likeable characters. No airheads or stupidity here.
- Decent length; my playtime is slightly inflated, it should take around 6-8 hours to complete.

Cons:

- Character illustrations ocassionally off model.
- Very limited animation, some lip-flap and blinking is the extent of animation.
- Kenetic story means no opportunity to explore areas of personal interest.

reviewText:
This is not really a video game. This is a kinetic novel, a visual novel that plays without any player decisions. It compares more with a novel or a movie, so those looking for anything resembling 99% of video games should look elsewhere, but those who are looking for an excellent story may look no further.

As a game that is entirely based upon story, eden* delivers.

eden* is a character-driven experience. Plot twists are used sparingly, and the story flows about as how you would expect. It is in the characters that the game shines. None of them resemble any cookie-cutter archetypes, especially those commonly found in anime or other visual novels. They feel human. They have a million different things on their mind, and the emotions attached to them are incredibly complex, and the game isn't afraid of discussing those conflicts inside each of those characters. It is especially apparent with the two lead characters' interactions; they understand each other's complexities almost absurdly well. It's a great joy seeing them change in even some minute ways as they face the very end.

The orchestral soundtrack is excellent and accents the story very well. The visuals are refreshingly more dynamic than most other visual novels, showing scenes from camera angles" beyond the usual cut-and-paste sprite approach. Hearing different voices in different ears depending on the placement of the "camera" is a nice touch if you wear headphones.

As for downsides
date: the game is a little short. My record is a little bloated from semi-frequent breaks and waiting to hear all of the voice acting before continuing. Summary
The earth is about to be smashed to bits by a red star. Having known this for 100 years a certain someone was instrumental in creating a space program so man could escape. People were not given a choice on if they could stay and die so many were outraged. Some also refused to believe the end would ever come. Thus the world has been in a constant state of martial law style war. The main male character is former special forces and a ruthless killer in his own eyes totally full of sin. Will he and the countless other people he meets find an internal sense of redemption or a way to atone for the immense guilt they feel?

Positive
Well obviously art and sound are top notch for a VN. I mean just watch the preview video. The story has a nice way of coming full circle and telling stories within stories. The whole story itself is by no means short like most VN titles bosting over 10 hours of story.

Negative
It ends up very difficult for a rational person to find any point in some of the decisions made since there is really no reason things had to turn out so heart wrenching if you think about it after your done with the game. This is a kinetic novel so choices do not exist. It's actually kind of a shame that choices don't exist because the option to make this into a Clannad type visual novel would have made more sense even if the story suffered slightly. In the end this game reminded me a lot of Clannad the anime series because it felt like it was purposely set up for feels even when it didn't make a whole lot of sense.

Conclusion
If you don't mind emotional stories with well developed characters this is a must. So far it is the best VN I've experience on steam easily beating the rest. Unlike many other steam VN's that have hentai on other sites this one has it available on other sites, but it actually is separate and makes little sense with the game if you go that route. Thus the steam version is actually better in my opinion because it won't make you wonder about that other content that makes little sense with the story. Even if I do think the story purposely makes the reader sad by having the characters purposely choose the more painful route even though there were way better options available I still respect it none the less.

Value
I would say about $15. To be honest I usually don't value VN games at a high value so this is actually rather up there for me. Especially since I normally say $1 per hour of gameplay. Except this time the story, sound, and slight animations make it worth the extra $0.50 an hour.

This kinetic novel follows the point of view of a young man who has seen more combat than he should have. He enters a mysterious facility and meets a girl who has more to her than meets the eye. No, I promise you I have not confused eden* with Planetarian. That said, if you enjoyed Planetarian, then I think you are very likely to enjoy eden*.

The visuals in eden* are good. In addition to having a variety of poses and facial expressions for each character, the characters are shown to blink and their lips sync with the voice acting. There are many CGs and each one is beautiful to see. Several locations even have multiple CGs and this gives the impression of a changing camera angle. I like it.

As eden* is a visual novel, the topic of H-scenes should be raised. I did some research and discovered that the H-scenes are apparently bonus content to unlock in the main menu after completing the kinetic novel once. This means that the H-scenes are not at all relevant to developing the canon storyline. So don‚Äôt worry about characters suddenly referring to something that happened during a deleted H-scene. That said, I also read that the H-scenes add more depth to each character despite being non-canon. Anyway, it should be well known now that if you want to see H-scenes then you should buy directly from MangaGamer.

The sound is good. The background music sets the mood well. However, it does not loop well because the end of the music fades to silence before starting again. The voice acting is good. I did not find any characters irritating to listen to. I think the emotions contained in the voice acting were appropriate for each character and the situation.

The story is told using flashbacks, and it makes some of the plot developments easy to see coming. The setting is easy to follow. The plot is decent and enjoyable, but it is not great. The translation is good. There are a few instances when I think a native English speaker would find the text unnatural but the text is still grammatically correct so it can still be understood.

Overall, I enjoyed eden* and recommend it to people who enjoy visual/kinetic novels. It is not a great kinetic novel, but it is good enough to deserve a place in the visual/kinetic novel library.

This is one of my favorite visual novels by far, I have of course read it entirely despite the hours played. Thats just becuse i'm a bit of a pervert and decided i'd rather read the 18+ version, which btw changes the story in no way. It just adds some extra bonus 'alternate' scenes if you know what I mean. ;)

First things first this is a kinetic novel, in other words there are NO choices, and therefore only one ending. The closest parallel I can draw from the steam library is Planetatian, which btw is another great kinetic novel, if a bit shorter.

The story in this one is for the most part pretty predictable, in so much as you know what the ending is going to be basically from the get go. This is not actually a problem though as for this visual novel, it is the journey, not the destination that you will enjoy. The plot is vaguely similar to the anime plastic memories if you have seen it, and if you have then you will know to prepare for some hardcore emotions throughout, so make sure to pack some tissues.

I liked all of the characters and enjoyed their interactions with each other, although the main character was perhaps a bit unlikable at the start but by the end he had really grown on me.

The animation and CG design was really top notch, the artwork is one of the best i've seen visual novel wise. The soundtrack was good as well, really fitting the mood for the most part.

To sum up, this is an amazing visual novel and is well worth your time to read it. Having said that, this is my first real review so It may be a bit shoddily written but I hope I have articulated how good this is.

9/10 Characters: The character development was magnificent and each character has more to them than just their looks. Every character shows their stupidity and smarts in different subjects. I was hesitating to play it because the character art is uninspiring. There are chlich√©s like oversized breasts, a cute army girl and a cute housemaiden. Part of me was afraid a cute magical cat-girl would appear next but thankfully I was spared this. Luckily the protagonist is not some silly perverted fool tripping into his own personal harem he has secretly dreamed for but a rather cold-hearted war veteran, and there are a couple other characters of that sort that you wouldn't necessarily expect in your more ordinary anime.

Despite some initial bumps and doubts the game is rather profound and thoughtful and has a better world and story to tell than most other KNs/VNs I have played. Their unoriginal exterior and clich√©-like introductions aside the characters were likeable and quite well written and had more depth than meets the eye. The game features a pretty interesting pre-apocalyptic sci-fi scenario that has you experience the final phases of mankind fleeing earth due to a bright red star that appeared in the sky and is said to destroy it. It's featuring some genuine sci-fi elements but isn't dwelling on the technical terms of it as much, it's more about the people and how they handle it all. This and the extensively designed background art (particularily skies and clouds) remind me fondly of the Makoto Shinkai animes that I had seen many years back.

The music deserves some mentioning too; there is plenty of it, it fits the situations nicely and is memorable. I intentionally stopped progressing at times just so I could listen to it more. It features contemplating, sad and upbeat tunes and I wasn't surprised to see that other players were wondering if it was available separately (it isn't in the West afaik, but there is a playlist in the main menu and I guess one can try YouTube or sorts).

Despite some initial bumps and doubts the game is rather profound and thoughtful and has a better world and story to tell than most other KNs/VNs I have played. Their unoriginal exterior and clich√©-like introductions aside the characters were likeable and quite well written and had more depth than meets the eye. The game features a pretty interesting pre-apocalyptic sci-fi scenario that has you experience the final phases of mankind fleeing earth due to a bright red star that appeared in the sky and is said to destroy it. It's featuring some genuine sci-fi elements but isn't dwelling on the technical terms of it as much, it's more about the people and how they handle it all. This and the extensively designed background art (particularily skies and clouds) remind me fondly of the Makoto Shinkai animes that I had seen many years back.

The music deserves some mentioning too; there is plenty of it, it fits the situations nicely and is memorable. I intentionally stopped progressing at times just so I could listen to it more. It features contemplating, sad and upbeat tunes and I wasn't surprised to see that other players were wondering if it was available separately (it isn't in the West afaik, but there is a playlist in the main menu and I guess one can try YouTube or sorts).

The premise is pretty solid for this one and I think the execution does it justice, though the game does lose a bit of momentum in its second half, and the last act of the game is kind of a slog similar to sitting through a funeral. But overall, I enjoyed it. The art is good, the music is good, the story's not too long, the characters, while maybe a bit mary sue-ish, feel real enough to keep me engaged in their interactions, and the ambiguous nature of the main plot is probably for the best; doesn't really need to be an exact answer for everything. The romantic aspects are generally sidelined and only come into play near the end (maybe why the ending felt like a slog for me) but there's enough of a buildup and character development that it's not really bothersome. Do note that this is a VN with no choices whatsoever, literally just a visual novel that you read/look at/listen to etc. But it works fine for the story. So yeah. Mildly pleasant overall, doesn't really feel like it drags on much, and there's plenty of heart to it.\n\nThe heck is up with the intro though, doesn't really fit in with the tone of the game at all.
